title: How to Make Buttercream Fondant

steps.headline: Put the light corn syrup and white shortening into a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (300 g) of light corn syrup into the bowl of a stand mixer and add 1 cup (190 g) of white shortening or softened butter. If you don't want to use corn syrup, substitute glucose syrup. If you don't have a stand mixer, combine the dough in a mixing bowl.

steps.headline: Stir in the salt and clear vanilla extract.
steps.description: Use the hook attachment on a stand mixer and turn it to low. While the mixer is running, add 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of clear vanilla extract. If you're using shortening, consider adding ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of butter extract to give your fondant a buttercream flavor. Although you can use regular vanilla extract, it makes your fondant slightly tinted. If you don't have a stand mixer, use a wooden spoon to combine the ingredients.

steps.headline: Mix in 2 pounds (0.91 kg) of powdered sugar.
steps.description: Keep the mixer on low speed and slowly add the powdered sugar. Once you've added all of the powdered sugar, turn the mixer to medium and beat the fondant until it's stiff.Tip: If you're using butter instead of shortening, add 2 tablespoons of cornstarch when you add the powdered sugar. The cornstarch stabilizes the butter, which makes it easier to handle. To mix the fondant by hand, turn it out onto a powdered-sugar coated surface and knead it by hand to make a stiff dough.

steps.headline: Add a few drops of food coloring if you want to make colorful fondant.
steps.description: Turn off the mixer and squirt about 5 or 6 drops of food coloring into the fondant. Then, turn the mixer to high speed and beat the fondant until the color is uniform. Keep adding more food coloring until the fondant is as vibrant as you like.

steps.headline: Roll out the fondant or store it until you're ready to use it.
steps.description: You can immediately start working with the fondant, but wrap it if you don't plan on rolling it out right away. To prevent the buttercream fondant from drying out, wrap it tightly in plastic wrap and put it into an airtight container. Store the fondant at room temperature for up to 1 week. Although refrigerating the fondant extends storage time, refrigeration introduces moisture which makes the fondant too sticky to roll out.

steps.headline: Coat a cake with a thin layer of buttercream frosting.
steps.description: Place a cooled cake on a turntable and apply buttercream frosting to the top and sides of the cake with an offset spatula. Smooth the buttercream and keep the layer thin since the frosting is just there to help the fondant stick.Tip: To make it easier to apply the fondant, refrigerate the cake for 30 minutes once you frost it. This may prevent the fondant from slipping off when you lay it on the cake. If you don't want to use buttercream frosting, use a thin layer of ganache or jam.

steps.headline: Dust your work surface with powdered sugar and put the fondant on it.
steps.description: Sprinkle a generous amount of powdered sugar over your counter and get it on your hands to prevent them from sticking to the fondant. Place the fondant on the counter and knead it a few times. If you're concerned that the fondant may still stick, try rolling the fondant out between 2 pieces of parchment paper instead.

steps.headline: Use a rolling pin to roll the fondant until it's at least ⁄8 inch (0.32 cm) thick.
steps.description: Turn the fondant frequently as you roll it out to prevent sticking and roll the fondant until it's a circle that's large enough to cover your cake. If you're covering a square or rectangular shape, roll the fondant so it's large enough to cover the top and sides of your cake.

steps.headline: Drape the fondant over the cake and press it to the sides.
steps.description: Roll the fondant so it hangs over your rolling pin and transfer it to the frosted cake. Unroll the fondant so it hangs over the sides of the cake. Then, use your hands or a fondant smoother tool to press the fondant against the top and sides of the cake. Buy a fondant smoother tool at craft supply stores, grocery stores, or online.

steps.headline: Trim excess fondant from the base of the cake and decorate the cake.
steps.description: Take a paring knife and carefully cut the excess fondant from the bottom edge of the cake. Save the fondant to roll out and make cut-out decorations. Brush a little buttercream on each decoration before you stick it onto the cake. For a fun look, make fondant roses, bows, or patterns to use on the finished cake.
